turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: Ohhh, I hate this.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Take your time.  Don't worry about the elves.  They won't come out here.

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: Why not?

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: This is not going well.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Hurry!  Queen Cherlindrea will know what to do.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Talk!  Say something!

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: I can't see anything--she's too bright!

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Hey, careful there!

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: How do these work I wonder?  I got- ta save one to show the High Aldwin.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Its branches are supposed to be made of gold, solid gold.

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: How are we going to get out there?

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: We've traveled a long way.  We're looking for Fin Raziel.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: The sorceress.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Obviously.

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: Without Raziel we'll never find Tir Asleen.  We'd better go.

turns.speaker: WILLOW
turns.text: This can't be right.  This isn't a sorceress.  This is some kind of animal.

turns.speaker: TEEMO
turns.text: Queen Bavmorda transformed her.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Sure, I'm sorry. Hope you don't mind me plugging in to your battery. Mine's dead... How can I help? What can I do?

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Maybe milking.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Milking?

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Cows. You know, cows?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I've seen pictures.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Good, you start tomorrow.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Didn't you hear me, Book? Pull! You never had your hands on a teat before?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Not one this big.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Eat up, Book. What's the matter with your appetite?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Guess I'm not used to so much.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Not used to hard work. That's what makes an appetite.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: How could you do this to me tonight? I told you I had company

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Sorry. It's important.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Where's Timmy and Buck?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Upstairs, asleep. Where'd you think?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You've got a man here and the kids are upstairs?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: That's none of your goddamn business! So keep your goddamn holier-than- thou mouth shut!  Anyway, they like Fred.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Oh sure, Fred.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Who are these orphans, anyway?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: They're Amish.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Put my car in the garage and close the door.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: John, I don't understand any of this.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You don't know anything... borrowed your car. Didn't say why. And you never heard of that woman and her boy.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: John, why?...

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Just do it!

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: Good morning. Book, is it? You are the Yankee they talk about?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I thought I was the English.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: English, Yankee. It's the same. My name is Daniel. Daniel Hochstetler.  You look plain, Book.  Very plain.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: I came to see Rachel Lapp.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Try the house.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: Eli says you're a carpenter, Book.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: It's been a while.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: No matter. Come with me. We can always use a good carpenter.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: Your hole is healed, then?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Pretty much.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: Nail it!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: HOCHSTETLER
turns.text: Everything is all right, John.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Pick up the hat.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: I saw him.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Who'd you see?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Who'd you see, Sam? The man on the floor?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: No... I saw the man who killed him.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: He was... like him.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Black... I understand. What else,Sam?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You ever handle a pistol like this, Samuel?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: No pistol. Ever.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Tell you what  I'm going to let you handle this one. But only if you promise not to say anything to your momma. I've got a feeling she wouldn't understand.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Okay, Mr. Book.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: That's Luke. He doesn't like strangers.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You don't say.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Hey, Sam...

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: ...I want to say a thing.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: What's that, Sam?

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Is it them?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: It's them, Sam.  Now, Sam, listen to me and listen to me carefully. Listen to me as you never listened before.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Are they going to kill you?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Listen to me, Sam! I want you to go across the new corn to Stoltzfus'. Run as fast as you can. And stay there!

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: What are you going to do?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'll be all right. You just do as I say.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Don't let them hurt you.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I won't. Now run.  Fast as you can!

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Are you really ever coming back?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Got to, Sam. You and I are going to a courthouse together, put some people behind bars.

turns.speaker: SAMUEL
turns.text: Have you got your gun on now?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Sure have, Sam.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: How reliable is this kid?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Oh, he's good.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Amish.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: What have you got?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Zenovitch was about to deliver a list of names tonight  street chemists... the guys processing this P2P into speed.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: So one of them got to him.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You know who?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Maybe.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You're still convinced there's a link to the department?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: If there isn't I've just wasted the last six months.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: That's the problem. We need results. The press is driving us crazy over this P2P thing. Calling us the 'speed capitol of the country'. You know the sort of thing. It's getting political. The Commissioner's getting very uneasy.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: The Amish boy saw him, Paul. I'll make it, but Set Donahue and the Homicide Department off my back or they'll blow the whole thing.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: When word gets out that Zenovitch was a cop, all hell will break lose. You've got 24 hours. That's all I can give you. 24 hours on your own. After that the case and the witness go back to the Homicide Department.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Tell you what... why don't you and that blonde  what's-her-name  come over for dinner Sunday. How 'bout that.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: What's-her-name moved to Buffalo.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Well, anyway, don't get crazy.  I'll do something for Zenovich's wife.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Last guy I would have figured. But he's part of it.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: I hope you don't have any doubts about that.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: If I did, I'd have kept my mouth shut...  It fits, Paul... Fifty-five gallons of P2P confiscated four years ago... Guess who was in on the collar? Mac.  He salts it away somewhere... he knows the stuff is potent, but the street chemists haven't figured out how to process it. But they do now.  And now the stuff is worth five-grand a pint and there are a lot of pints in a fifty-five gallon drum.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Who else knows?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Just us.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Okay, what are you going to need to clean it up

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: More people... Gotta pick up where Zenovich left off. People from outside the department.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Maybe the Bureau. Or those bastards at Treasury. I'll take care of it.  I hate this shit, Johnny. You cut their balls off for me. I'm counting on you.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: What's your first move?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: A hot shower... I haven't changed clothes in two days.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Who else knows?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Just us.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You made a mistake, Paul. You shouldn't have taken Elton out.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: How bad did Mac get you? We figured pretty bad.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'm fine. I'm going to live a long time. That's what I called to tell you.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Johnny 

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You might want to pass it along to Mac.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Listen to me, Johnny. Come in! You're out there all alone... We're getting close... real close... Maybe if you listen to me for a minute we can work something out so you can come in 

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I've already got something worked out.  Be seeing you.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You're going to have to do it right here, Schaeffer.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Don't try me, Johnny!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: It's all over, Paul.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Move! Or you die right here!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'm a police officer. I'm going to have to talk to the boy. What's his name?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Samuel. Samuel Lapp.  But what happened here is none of his affair. My sister is expecting me... our train is leaving soon.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: There'll be another train.  The man who was killed tonight was a policeman, Sam. It's my job to find out who did it. I want you to tell me everything you saw when you went in there.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Where are you taking us?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: We're looking for a suspect. We've reason to believe he's still in the area.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You have no right to keep us here.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Yes I do. Your son is a material witness to a homicide.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You don't understand, we have nothing to do with your laws!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Doesn't surprise me. I meet a lot of people like that.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: It's not a joke.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: What was that?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: He wants to know who you are. Your name. I told him we don't need to know anything about you.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Now what's the problem?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: The problem is I don't happen to think my son should be spending all his time with a man who carried a gun under his coat and goes around whacking people.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Whacking?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes. And I also want to leave this city.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Believe me, I'm trying to get this over with as fast as I can. But Samuel will probably have to come back and testify.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: We do not go into your courts.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: People who don't go into our courts when they're told to sometimes go directly into our jail.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Look, I'm genuinely sorry...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No you're not   You're glad, because now you've got a witness.  I heard the other police talking last night.  They don't seem to like you very much.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: They kid a lot.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I would not be too sure.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But not a good tired.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: What's a 'good' tired. Tired is tired.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Your sister said you don't have a family?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: She thinks you should get married and have children of your own. Instead of trying to be a father to hers. Except she thinks you're afraid of the responsibility.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Oh? Anything else?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Oh yes. She thinks you like policing because you think you're right about everything. And you're the only one who can do anything. And that when you drink a lot of beer you say things like none of the other police would know a crook from a... um... bag of elbows.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Why don't you arrest that man? Are you protecting him because policeman?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Listen, I'm the cop that polices the police. I'm not in the business of protecting crooked cops.  I'll make an arrest when I know everybody involved.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But why would they murder...

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Because  somehow  they knew I was getting close.  Look, it's narcotics... They make dope out of chemicals... they sell it on the street for millions of dollars. They'll do anything.  And they can get away with it because they're cops.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm afraid. I'm afraid for Samuel. I want to go home.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: You'll be safe. You don't have to worry.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Where are you taking us now?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Home.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You couldn't wait until morning?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You said we would be safe in Philadelphia.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I was wrong.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Stay for awhile. Rest. I'll make coffee and breakfast.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I can't.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: What about Samuel? Will you come back to take him to trial?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But John... why didn't you go to a hospital?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: No, no doctor...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But why?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Gunshot... they'll file reports... they'll find me.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But 

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Who are they?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: The leadership of our district... the diener. Bishop Tschantz is the one with no hair on top. They decided to come and see you for themselves. Except Stoltzfus, of course. He came the first day. I think he saved your life.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Can I have something to drink?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Does anybody know I'm here?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Only the elders.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: How long?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: How long have I been here?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Two days.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Listen, thank you. Thanks for everything. But I've got to go.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But you can't.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Tell him his tea stinks.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You tell him. When you're able.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: John Book, I would appreciate it if, during the time you are with us, you would have as little to do with Samuel as possible.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Nobody meant any harm. The boy was curious. I unloaded the gun -

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: It's not the gun. Don't you understand... It's you. What you stand for.  That is not for Samuel.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Enjoying your reading?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Very interesting. I'm learning a lot about manure.  What's that?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Your shirt and jacket are still stained with blood. I have them soaking.You can wear these.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Your husband's?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes. It's good that someone can have the use of them. Besides, in your clothes you'd stand out to strangers.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I should tell you these do not have buttons.  See? Hooks and eyes.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Something wrong with buttons?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Buttons are Hochmut.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Hochmut?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Vain. Proud. Such a person is Hochmutsnarr. He is not plain.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Anything against zippers?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You make fun of me. Like the tourists. Driving by all the time. Some even come into the yard. Very rude. They seem to think we are quaint.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Quaint? Can't imagine why.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Where's the nearest telephone?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Telephone? The Gunthers across the valley. They're Mennonite. They have cars and refrigerators and telephones in the houses even.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: No. I'd want a public phone.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Well... the store at Saltzburg...  But you won't be going to Saltzburg for a while.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'm going this morning.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But Stoltzfus said...

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I know what he said.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You can go with Eli. He's taking Samuel to school. But you'll have to hurry.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: The... bullets?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Oh. The bullets.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Eli is a fine carpenter. Best in the district. He and his father built the big house themselves forty years ago.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Oh?  What happened to Hochstetler?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: We had some lemonade and he left.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: A real fireball.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You know carpentry?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I did some carpentry summers when I was going to school.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: What else can you do?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I can whack people. I'm hell at whacking.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Whacking is not of much use on a farm.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Now hold on. There's a lot of people who think being a cop is a legitimate job.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm sorry. I'm sure it is.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Sure.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: But... You may not be well enough.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'll drink some more of Stoltzfus' tea.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: When will you be going?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Not long... A few days.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Won him over just like that.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I see.  But I hope you have a lot of sugar.  Eli is ready to go to Zook's.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You should not bother with that birdhouse.  If you're leaving tomorrow.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'm leaving tonight.  I'm going to need my clothes. And my gun.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: There was a time when I thought you might have stayed.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: There was.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: There was a time when I would have welcomed it.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I was being foolish?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: No.  I was being unrealistic. Even thinking about living this life.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You're so sure of that?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Aren't you? After today?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I'm not so sure of anything as you are, John Book. You could live this life if you wanted to bad enough.  Just as I could live yours!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Oh, come on, Rachel. No way.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: There is always a way! But you are such a... a Glotzkopp you cannot see! You'd rather go back to that city! To nothing! No woman! No children! No land!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Land! Are you crazy? I'm no Amishman and I'm no farmer! I'm a cop. That's what I know and that's what I do!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: What you do is take vengeance! Which is a sin against heaven!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: That's your way, not mine.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: That's God's way!

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Well in the City of Philadelphia, God needs a little help!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I want you to take this... to remember by.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Where's my baggy pants?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Here. Whenever you want them.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Anybody know about this?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I didn't even know about it.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Okay, Sam. Can you tell me what he looked like?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I got there late, John.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Let's just find Coalmine.  Listen, Zenovich made a mistake. You didn't let anybody down. It happens 

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: It won't happen again.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Listen carefully, I wrote the Amish woman's name and address on my desk calendar, I want you to lose it for me, Now. Tonight.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What the hell are you talking about? What's happening.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Nothing. I'm not going to be around for a while. I'll call you when I can.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Johnny, what the fuck?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Listen to me  Schaeffer's part of it. Maybe at the top of it.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Yeah... I can put it all together when I get back, 'Til then, you know nothing, understand? Business as usual...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I hear you.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Good. Take care of that woman's name for me. And watch your ass.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: It's me.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Johnny! Where the hell have you been?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Never mind. I'm coming in to take care of business. How hot am I?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Too hot. Don't do it. Don't come in.

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I'm coming.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Listen, Johnny, don't do anything stupid. You couldn't get within a mile of Schaeffer right now. So stay put... Stay in touch  I'll let you know when maybe it makes sense.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: You hear me?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: I hear you. I'll stay in touch.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: That's more like it.  Where are you at, anyway?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Where I'm at is maybe 1890.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Say again?

turns.speaker: BOOK
turns.text: Make that 1790.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You know where he is.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Wrong.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You'd lie to protect him.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: Probably.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You admit you're lying?

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: I admit I don't know where he is.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: You're the first one he'll contact.

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: He's got my number.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Either you're a member of the club or you aren't, Elton.  Tell me what you know...

turns.speaker: CARTER
turns.text: What I know, Paul, is...  He's going to take you out...

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Did you find him?

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Not yet.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Elaine, I've come to apologize for Lt. McElroy. He overstated the department's position.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: He accused John of taking kickbacks. And you know  anybody who knows John  knows that's a goddamn lie!

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Of course, Elaine. But as long as there's any question, better Johnny should come back and clear his name.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Better you should get off my front porch before I get my mace!

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Elaine, I don't want to have to take you in for questioning. You've got his car, you were the last to see him 

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: I don't know where he is.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: But... if you had to guess?

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Everything okay?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes, thank you very much.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: John said you're Amish.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Good morning.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You didn't have to...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I wanted to. you were kind to take us in last night.  Anyway, I needed something to do. I was so angry with your brother. He's so... agaanisish!

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Aganishish? Yeah, that sounds like John.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Just a minute. I'll pour you some coffee.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: You're not carrying a bullwhip... how'd you manage to put my kids to work?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I made it a contest... the one who does best gets his cereal back first.  Children like to help... they only need to be kept after a little bit.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: What's so funny?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Fred. The way he looked when you screamed at him.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: God, Fred...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: At home you'd never hear a woman scream at a man that way.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: No? Why not?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You just wouldn't. It's not the Amish way.  But I think it would have done me good if I could have screamed at your brother last night.

turns.speaker: ELAINE
turns.text: Listen, I don't know what's going on or how you got mixed up with him, but don't you let that self-righteous son of a bitch push you around, okay?

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Who was that man?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: His name is John Book.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Is the English dead?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Looks dead...

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: That has no place in this house.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Didn't you hear Stoltzfus? What if he dies? Then the sheriff will come. They'll say we broke their laws 

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: We'll pray that he doesn't die! But if he does, then we'll find a way so no one knows!

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Rachel, this is a man's life, we hold it in our hands.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I know God help me, I know that, Eli.  But I tell you that if he's found here, the people who did this to him will come for Samuel.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Eli, John is a carpenter.  As well as being a fine policeman.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Eh? Well then, maybe he can go to Zook's barn-raising, eh? See how good a carpenter.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: How can this be? How can you do such a thing? Is this plain? Is this the ordnung?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I have done nothing against the ordnung.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Eh? Nothing? Rachel, you bring this man to our house. With his gun of the hand. You bring fear to this house. Fear of English with guns coming after. You bring blood and whispers of more blood. Now English music... and you are dancing to English music! And you call this nothing?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I have committed no sin.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: No sin? Maybe. Not yet. But, Rachel, it does not look...  Don't you know there has been talk? Talk about you, not him. Talk about going to the Bishop. About having you... shunned!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: That is idle talk.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: Do not make light of it, Rachel. They can do it... quick! Like that! And then... then I can not sit at table with you. I can not take a thing from your hand. I... I can not go with you to meeting!  Rachel, good Rachel, you must not go too far! Dear child!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I am not a child.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: You are acting like one!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I will be the judge of that.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: No! They will be the judge of that! And so will I... if you shame me!

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You shame yourself.

turns.speaker: ELI
turns.text: No, Rachel...

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: I have to help him!

turns.speaker: LOCAL MAN
turns.text: Never seen anything like that in all my years.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: He's from... Ohio... My cousin.

turns.speaker: LOCAL MAN
turns.text: We'll, them Ohio Amish sure must be different.  Our Lancaster brethren, they just don't have that kind of fight in them.

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: John, lost control of himself. He... will be repentant.

turns.speaker: LOCAL MAN
turns.text: You're Rachel Lapp, aren't you?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: Yes. Samuel! We're going.

turns.speaker: MCELROY
turns.text: She say where he is?

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: I don't think she knows.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: What about Carter?

turns.speaker: MCELROY
turns.text: Tight. But I'm working on him.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Lean on him.

turns.speaker: MCELROY
turns.text: Weird, man. No fuckin' electricity. What do you figure they plug all their shit into?

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: They don't have any shit.

turns.speaker: MCELROY
turns.text: He's not in this building.

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: All right, where is he?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: No, you listen. Get out!

turns.speaker: SCHAEFFER
turns.text: Lady, I'm here to help you. This man is very dangerous. An armed criminal.  He's got a gun, hasn't he?

turns.speaker: RACHEL
turns.text: You have no right here!
